conversation.aPrompt: How do I enroll my child in kindergarten in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: To enroll your child in school (kindergarten is implied as a type of school) in Romania, contact the County Schools Inspectorate to obtain an application.  Fill out the application, indicating if you need psycho-pedagogical assistance. Submit the application in person or via email.  The application will be processed within one day, and the Inspectorate will contact you to discuss class placement.  For Ukrainian children learning Romanian, special provisions are made.  In Bucharest during summer, online applications may be sent to office@ismb.ro and felix.goldbach@ismb.ro.  If you are a newly arrived unaccompanied minor or mother/adult with children, register with the General Directorate of Social Assistance and Child Protection for necessary assistance. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: How to enroll a child in school, kindergarten or extracurricular activities

conversation.aPrompt: What is the process for enrolling a child in extracurricular activities in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: First, contact the County Schools Inspectorate using the provided contact list.  Second, complete the extracurricular activity application (available online or in person), specifying any needed psycho-pedagogical assistance.  Third, submit the application (in person or via email) and the Inspectorate will contact you within one day to discuss placement.  The final placement will be decided after a meeting with the responsible commission. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education

conversation.aPrompt: What documents are needed to enroll a child in school in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: To enroll a child in school, you need to fill out an application for enrolling the child in school with the audiences statute.  This application can be downloaded online or obtained from the County School Inspectorate.  If you want your child to receive psycho-pedagogical assistance and counseling, check that option on the application.  For Ukrainian children learning Romanian, the County School Inspectorates will provide necessary conditions and resources. The application can be submitted in person or online via email to the County School Inspectorate.  To change a child's status from trainee to student, you need to send the necessary documents (available on the ISMB website) to the Bucharest School Inspectorate. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education

conversation.aPrompt: How can I continue my studies in Romania if I'm a current or former student?
conversation.bResponse: To continue your studies in Romania, go directly to the desired university.  Enrollment is possible even without complete documentation, using a self-declaration of prior studies, though university-specific evaluation processes apply.  Before completing your studies, you must provide Romanian higher education institutions with diplomas granting access to your enrolled study cycle.  For diploma equivalence, contact the National Center for Diploma Recognition and Equivalence (CNRED)  to equate your existing diplomas, necessary for further study enrollment.  If you've completed your studies, CNRED evaluates and recognizes study documents for further studies or labor market access.  To obtain a recognition certificate, submit a file including an application (physical submission only), diploma/certificate copies (translated if not in Romanian, English, French, Spanish, or Italian), school records, ID, and a 100 RON fee (except for those with international protection). Documents may require apostille or superlegalization. File submission is online (through the Electronic Single Point of Contact), at the university, or at the Ministry of Education's Registry.  CNRED will respond within 30 working days, with extensions possible.  Certificates are obtained electronically, from the university, or CNRED.  Appeals against CNRED decisions are submitted to the Ministry of Education's registry within 45 working days. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

conversation.aPrompt: What documents do I need to have my foreign study credentials recognized in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: To have your foreign study credentials recognized, you need to submit an application (if submitting physically), copies of your high school diploma/certificate (and a certified translation if not in Romanian, English, French, Spanish, or Italian), copies of your school records for the last two years of study (and a certified translation if needed), a copy of your personal identification, a 100 RON evaluation fee (unless you have international protection), and any other relevant documents.  Documents may require apostille or superlegalization depending on their country of origin.  A detailed list of required documents is available. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

conversation.aPrompt: Where can I submit my application for diploma recognition in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: You can submit your application online through the Electronic Single Point of Contact (depending on the language your diploma is issued in), physically at the university where you wish to enroll, at the Registry of the Ministry of Education (in person or by mail/courier), or by mail/express courier to the Registry of the Ministry of Education at Str. Spiru Haret no. 12, ground floor, room 1, Sector 1, 010176 Bucharest. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

conversation.aPrompt: How long does the diploma recognition process in Romania typically take?
conversation.bResponse: The evaluation takes a maximum of 30 working days from the date of registration of the complete file.  This deadline may be extended if further checks are required.  Appeals take up to 60 working days to resolve, with potential extensions. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

conversation.aPrompt: What are my options if my diploma recognition application is rejected in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: If your application is rejected, you can file an appeal with the registry of the Ministry of Education within 45 working days of the rejection.  The Ministry will then have 60 working days (potentially longer in justified cases) to resolve the appeal. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
conversation.cSubject: If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

conversation.aPrompt: What support services are available for Ukrainian minors in Romania?
conversation.bResponse: Ukrainian minors under temporary protection in Romania, but not beneficiaries of international protection, receive free accommodation in school dormitories, a daily food allowance, and additional financial support for school supplies, bedding, clothing, and footwear. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
